review.title: When Learners Surpass their Sources: Mathematical Modeling of Learning from an Inconsistent Source
review.abstract: We present a new algorithm to model and investigate the learning process of a learner mastering a set of grammatical rules from an inconsistent source. The compelling interest of human language acquisition is that the learning succeeds in virtually every case, despite the fact that the input data are formally inadequate to explain the success of learning. Our model explains how a learner can successfully learn from or even surpass its imperfect source without possessing any additional biases or constraints about the types of patterns that exist in the language. We use the data collected by Singleton and Newport (2004) on the performance of a 7-year boy Simon, who mastered the American Sign Language (ASL) by learning it from his parents, both of whom were imperfect speakers of ASL. We show that the algorithm possesses a frequency-boosting property, whereby the frequency of the most common form of the source is increased by the learner. We also explain several key features of Simon's ASL.

sections.heading: 2.2 Formulation of the algorithm
sections.text: The key idea of the algorithm presented in this paper is that the states altered by probabilistic input are probabilities themselves. Suppose a rule has only two forms, form 1 and form 2. In each instance of time, the learner is characterized by two numbers, X1 ≥ 0 and X2 ≥ 0, each corresponding to the probability of using the corresponding form of the rule (we impose X1 + X2 > 0). Specifically, the probability that the learner will use the form 1 is given by X1 / (X1 + X2), and the probability of the learner to use the form 2 is given by X2 / (X1 + X2). You can see that if X1 = 0, then form 2 is always used (the learner's language is consistent with the corresponding rule). Likewise, in X2, only form 1 is used.

sections.heading: 3 Properties of the learning algorithm
sections.text: An important application in our context is the consideration of a teacher-learner pair. In general, the teacher does not necessarily have to be a person, it could be a number of people, the only condition being that the statistics of the source do not change with time. To be more precise, we assume that the source is defined by non-negative numbers, namely 1,..., νM, with the probability that the source sends out each of the M forms of the rule. Thus, it can be assumed that the source is just an agent (whose values are "frozen" by Xi, i.e. not updated) or a collection of such non-updating agents. The situation with the teacher-learner pair can be used to model the language acquisition of a child by one or two parents and other adults whose language is frozen. In particular, it can be applied to the situation of Simon, who has only learned from his two parents.

sections.heading: 3.1 Analytical Results
sections.text: Consider the case M = 2, or the two alternative forms of the rule. We refer to the probability of the source to use form 1; form 2 is used with probability 1 -2. The amplification algorithms described above are probabilities, that is, if the Markov chain is in state i / L, the probability that the learner will use form 1 can be i / L... 1, with the constant L appearing in the description of the algorithm, Section 2.2. The states are probabilities, i.e. if the Markov chain is in state i / L, the probability that the learner will use form 1 is i / L... 1, this chain being modeled by the distribution vector [X0, X1,..., XL] at any point in time where Xi represents the probability that the chain is in state i / L. The distribution vector is updated step by step by multiplying the transition matrix.

sections.heading: 3.2 Numerical Simulations
sections.text: It is intuitive to talk about quantities, the increment of learning. This is the amount with which the probabilities change in each step, following the input of the source. The analytical results can be summarized as follows: M = 2 (the number of steps increases), the learner converts to a quasi-stationary state, in which he is characterized by the frequency of the form (3). This frequency is higher than the frequency of the source (the number of steps increases).

sections.heading: 4 Applications: Simon
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: This paper presents a model that explains the frequency-enhancing effect observed in children when learning a language. It presents a simple amplification type algorithm that represents successful learning without the learner having any explicit innate biases. In the case of two forms of the rule, the promoting property of the algorithm has been analytically proven and demonstrated numerically for a greater number of forms. Convergence speed and its dependence on parameters and source complexity have also been studied. Finally, the results were discussed in the context of the Singleton & Newport study (2004) to show that the simple model is capable of explaining several key features of Simon's performance and learning behavior.

(2004)) with rational Bayesian agents (Griffiths & Kalish, 2007), it was shown that language regularization can be achieved in the course of several generations of learners. This is an important mechanism that has also been documented by Smith & Wonnacott (2010), which studied the gradual, cumulative population-level processes giving rise to language regularity. In this paper we provide a mathematical framework that allows us to model regularization achieved within a single generation. We create a model (of the reinforcement-learner type) that allows us to study Simon’s learning behavior, as well as other situations of language regularization in adults and children. This rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we motivate the discussion of learning algorithms, and introduce a particular algorithm of the reinforcement type. Section 3 studies properties of this algorithm analytically and numerically. In particular, its frequency boosting property is demonstrated, and the speed of convergence investigated. Section 4 uses the algorithm to discuss the performance of Simon in Singleton & Newport (2004). Section 5 contains discussion and conclusions.
